In that context, it should be remembered that the criminal law is punishing offences against the community—those acts that society thinks are so bad that they ought to be visited with criminal sanctions. But it is sometimes thought by some that the criminal law is more a law that deals with disputes between people—the victim and the perpetrator. That is true to some extent but I think it is the wrong analysis of what the criminal law is all about and sometimes leads to demands, such as demands for victim impact statements, which are not as accurate as they should be.

There has been much talk of more women being put on the bench, and I certainly agree that that ought to happen. I point out here—it has been pointed out already, but I think it is a point worth making—that in the 1950s when my wife was studying law there were very few women in her class.

TALK.START.PARA: —Still are.
—No, the numbers are increasing. I think that is one of the reasons why not many women are judges. May I say that my wife would make an excellent and outstanding judge—
—She is a great judge of character.

—Yes. It is interesting in that context to understand—Senator Baume would understand this—that Monash University started training lawyers in the 1960s, getting on to 30 years ago. There is only one judge, Mr Justice Nahum Mushin, who has come from that university. As time goes by, there will be a lot more of them. It is an illustration that when we are looking at whether or not a proper approach has been taken to appointing judges, regard must be had to the fact that judges take some time to grow. It will be interesting to see how many women are on the bench at the turn of the century.

PARA.TAB: There is one other point I want to make about the appointment of judges in that context. I think it would be wrong to appoint judges on the basis that they reflect society. If we do that, as somebody said, five per cent of judges ought to be convicted criminals.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some would say they are.
—I don't think that would be likely.

—It is unlikely. But it illustrates that if there is a reflected principle, that is the sort of difficulty one comes across. What we want is a judiciary that understands the various sections of the community. We want a judiciary that is quite outstanding but, nevertheless, has an ability to understand the pressures and difficulties that people from all walks of life may have. It is the understanding that ought to be emphasised, rather than the reflected principles.

PARA.TAB: Different qualities are required of judges in different courts. A court with a jury would be best handled by people who know their rules of evidence, what should be allowed into evidence and what should not. Appeal tribunals need judges with different qualities. Senator Gareth Evans denies that he would ever go on the High Court but that is perhaps the one court that he would suit. I hope he does not come after me for saying that. I think Senator Evans would have the ability to be a great High Court judge whereas he might not have the ability to be a great judge at first instance—not that he could not learn up his evidence; but he has chosen to come to the Senate instead, where rules of evidence do not count.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't apply here at all, do they?

—No, they do not. Looking at the substantive law and trying to squeeze out of that any sexual or other bias is important. The judges who made the remarks that have been criticised and referred to were not making remarks out of the air. They were making their remarks on the basis of what they had grown up with at law school. The sorts of things they said were the sorts of things that were taught in law schools in the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s. So it is the substantive law that needs to be looked at. What the judges have to do is attach themselves to the changing law so the changing culture of the law is kept up with.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, in my view we have in Australia a very good judiciary. It is clear of corruption; it has considerable ability and has great respect. That does not mean that when it makes a statement that ought to be criticised, that the statement should not be. Criticism in the press has been good so far, as has already been said, and has led to this inquiry which I hope is of some use. But it would be a pity if we got to the point that the judiciary became fair game, simply because it is there. I hope this report has helped get to the position where criticism that has been passed, and will be passed in the future, is legitimate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a few remarks to the report on gender bias and the judiciary. The report is noteworthy for making three clear findings. The first is that there is a systemic gender bias in the law that includes sections of the judiciary. Secondly, the report rejects the notion that the problem will be resolved by evolution of time and changes in the composition of the bench. It argues that a more interventionist approach is required to eradicate gender bias in our legal system.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, the report makes recommendations for steps that can be taken to improve the legal system, provide better systems for judicial selection, education and accountability; and that those things can be done without interfering with the essential independence of judges. It is possible for the community to demand more accountability and involvement in these issues without interfering in the important concept of judicial independence.

Nothing in this report, in my view, would bring into question judicial independence; but it makes some very valid, commonsense suggestions for change. It reflects a mood for change that exists in the community. There is some concern not only about the cases examined by the committee in dealing with this report, but also about others, that the legal system reflects a bias against women—in the law, its interpretation, and in the composition of the judiciary.

I think there is a mood in the community to support positive change to improve our legal system. That mood of change is growing. From what I have read in the press, the reaction to the report from both commentators and a range of judicial officers has been very positive. It is important that we recognise that arguments for judicial independence cannot be allowed to prevent us attacking the question of bias in the legal system. We should not resile from the challenges and opportunities to improve and correct the system.

Much has been said about the role of the media in reporting these cases. There is a quite sensitive discussion of these issues in the report. I must say I fall on the side of those who are not quite as critical as others of the role the media played in reporting these cases, mainly because I think that by reporting them in that way the media have at least opened up the system to examination and forced the system to confront some of the criticisms that have been made. That is a good thing.

Obviously, there were some excesses and it would be better if court reporting were more sensitive and accurate. However, the legal system has to do more to explain the way it operates, its procedures and rules, and make information available to reporters so they can do their job better. That is one of the things the report tries to pick up. It is important that the law has to make the effort to be media friendly and accessible if it expects to be reported accurately.

I want to touch on one other issue that was debated by most of the speakers in this debate, especially Senator Ellison and Senator Cooney. I suppose the fact that I come to this issue as a non-lawyer might explain the fact that I hold a slightly different view from them, but maybe it is for other reasons. The issue is the trickle-down theory of the promotion of women in the law.

The argument was put to the committee by a number of witnesses—and I think it has been supported by a number of senators on the committee—that because an increasing number of women are entering law school, graduating as solicitors and practising in the system, concerns about the number of women who hold judicial appointments or the number of women who hold senior positions at the bar and their obvious lack of representation in those spheres ought not to be taken too seriously. It is argued that over the years, as these large numbers of women move through the system, the numbers of women at the bar and appointed to the judiciary will, through a natural process, represent more accurately the number of women in the wider community.

I am not an advocate of that trickle-down theory. I do not think that it is of itself right. I think there are a number of structural barriers to women progressing through the law and we need to take steps to address those issues. This debate is very similar to the debate regarding the problems that confront women who want to be actively involved in politics. Obviously, some barriers exist within the legal system. A number of the recommendations in this committee report will assist in opening up the system and therefore perhaps will help facilitate more women achieving appointment to the bar and to judicial positions.

Recommendations, such as those that go to encouraging a wider pool from which we draw our judges, will help. The opening up of the whole appointment system and selection criteria to public scrutiny will also assist in that process. If some of those things are done then we will start to attack what are structural barriers to having more women appointed to the bench. That is very important both in terms of providing women role models and having a more broadly based judiciary.

I take on board Senator Cooney's comments that we would not want to have a judiciary that exactly reflects the composition of society, but equally we would not want one that clearly does not represent society or that is clearly representative of a narrow group within society to the exclusion of others. I wanted to put on record the remarks about what I refer to as the trickle-down theory. I think I diverge from the views of some of my colleagues on the committee in relation to some of these issues. I commend this very comprehensive report to the Senate. I congratulate the staff for their good work again and my fellow senators for their contribution to the report. This report will be a useful addition to the debate on these issues which is occurring in Australian society.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on the legal and constitutional affairs committee's report on gender issues and the judiciary. Having had the opportunity to make some remarks on the day that this report was actually tabled during the break, I do not intend to take the Senate's time to repeat them, except for one aspect I did raise on that day that I think bears repeating in this place. This report in particular, among many others that come from committees, is an absolute triumph for the Senate committee system. It is an example of the Senate committee system working as it ought to work. I do not want to take away from contents of the report, but I refer particularly to the preparedness of the Senate to give the legal and constitutional affairs committee this reference.

PARA.TAB: As speakers have indicated, the report basically came about because of a rash of very bad publicity as a consequence of a number of remarks that have been made by judges either in sentencing or in summing up to juries, remarks which by and large were overturned on appeal. Nonetheless, the coverage given to those remarks, some of which was right over the top and out of perspective, had cumulatively created the impression in the community that by far the greater majority of our judges were ill-informed, sexist, out of date and in fact were creating the impression that people, and women in particular who were victims of sexual offences, did not stand much of a chance going before the courts.

That seemed to me to be a community concern that needed to be addressed fairly promptly and responsibly. A number of people took the view that the Senate had no business taking on this inquiry, that the independence of the judiciary should not be interfered with, that the court system would handle this, that where judges had made a mistake it would be overturned, and that we should take the attitude, vis-a-vis the publicity the judges had been getting, that they have to take—that is, let it ride, let the system work the problems out and if the criticism is ill informed, it will be shown to be so in good time. I did not share that view; and I do not do so for a number of reasons.

Firstly, I think the judges are in a difficult position. As one journalist put to me, they cannot sue someone who misreports what they have said. We cannot have the appropriateness, propriety or otherwise of remarks of judges when they are summing up or making remarks in sentencing settled in some other court proceedings. We cannot have civil proceedings on civil proceedings deciding what should have been said in criminal proceedings. This is just laughable.

The system is that judges say what they want to say and they are judged by their peers and by superior courts if they have made a mistake. But they have to keep out of public debate and the process decides whether they have done the right thing or not. We were left with the public debate and the judiciary were unable to participate in it for that reason.

We could have chosen to say, `Well, that is up to the judiciary, they are independent, we cannot interfere,' and let that community concern grow. I believe if we had done that by our inaction we would have been contributing to undermining the confidence Australians by and large have in the judiciary. So simply taking on this task was an achievement. I know from the heated debates I have had that a number of people did not want us to take up this reference. They see the separation of powers as preventing the parliament from saying something about the judiciary; that merely expressing views publicly is interfering. I do not share that view.

I think this report has been welcomed around Australia by judges and others, certainly by some law societies. I have seen the odd High Court judge's remarks being reported favourably. That in itself is not a test of a report. Basically, who cares if someone comes to a conclusion and thinks it is right—one goes with it. There may be Senate reports that some people criticise. There may be people who violently disagree with some aspects of this report. That is all well and good. If it contributes to the debate being more informed than it was at the time we took on this reference then that in itself will be an achievement.

Lastly, I want to make some remarks about this so-called trickle-down effect. A number of people have said with respect to the apparent paucity of women judges, `Well, it is all the system of appointment.' It may in part be that but there has been an increase in the number of women taking out a law degree, then practising and getting to the point where they can on merit compete for these positions. That was not the case 50 years ago. The number of women in law school has increased. In 20 or 30 years we will see more women taking positions on the bench simply because there are more women around who are capable of doing so.

I look forward to the day when that happens because, separate from the merit issue—which everyone has been at pains to say must be the key criterion—I do not think we can deny that many citizens, both male and female, find the first experience of a court, if they have one, absolutely daunting. I am sure there are people who do not look after their own interests as well as they could before a court because they are so terrified of the entire system and what will happen to them. In fact, I recall reading at one stage some research that it was not the penalties that frightened people into doing the right thing—it is the fear of ever having to go to court and be publicly dealt with. People find the system complex and therefore daunting and frightening. I believe that it is even more so for women, who up until fairly recently would go into a court where the judge, or judges, and most of the advocates were always male.

Just as the argument is made that when we have more women in politics—I know both of the major parties are trying to address that—we will be in a sense feminising politics, I think that could happen with the legal system. It does need a softer face if it is to be a system that is welcoming to all Australians, because that obviously includes women and particularly those without the benefit of the sort of education that most people in this place have had. Those who one might in other circumstances describe as disadvantaged do start off from behind when they go through such a daunting experience.

If, as I say, we have this greater influx of women on to the judiciary, they can contribute to humanising the court process. I am not talking about softening it up and giving people bags of lollies. I am talking about humanising it and making people feel more comfortable so that when they go through the system they have a more even chance than they feel they have now. If they are more relaxed and comfortable with the system, that in itself will be a good thing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate on 23 August 1990, on behalf of the President I table the 12th report of the Select Committee on Superannuation, entitled Super for housing, which was presented to the President on 13 May 1994. In accordance

PROCTEXT.PARA: with the terms of the resolution the President authorises the printing and circulation of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the transcript of evidence and submissions received by the committee relating to the report just tabled.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report that was presented to the President on 13 May 1994 by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation is a comprehensive and thorough coverage of an initiative which both major political parties took to the last election. It is, I believe, the most detailed document yet published on the subject. It is my view that the government should have waited for this report before jettisoning the super for housing scheme proposed in its 1993 election policy.

PARA.TAB: On the weight of the evidence presented to the committee, it is convinced that an effectively targeted and administered super for housing scheme could provide significant benefits to certain sections of the community. For this reason the committee recommends that the government give further consideration to the adoption of a super for housing policy.

There is no doubt that there is a genuine need to assist lower income earners obtain housing finance. There is no need for me to go into great detail about housing statistics, as these are presented in the report. However, the committee was concerned that, while housing costs consumed on average only 12.6 per cent of incomes of Australian households in 1988, many Australian households now have housing costs exceeding 25 to 30 per cent of their income. At the lower income levels, sole parents and couples with or without dependent children in the 35 to 64 age group spend average proportions exceeding 40 per cent in nearly all cases. Such expenditure is, for many, a major financial burden and a source of tremendous stress.

Of particular interest to the committee was the impact of home ownership on housing affordability in retirement and the correlation between lack of home ownership and the high levels of housing stress experienced by retired people who meet their accommodation need through the private rental market. Statistics from a number of sources indicate that those in retirement who do not own their own home and who are also wholly or partially dependent on the age pension normally live on or below the poverty line despite government rental assistance. Hence, there was much discussion during the hearings on the relative merits of savings in the form of superannuation versus saving in the form of home purchase.

The committee supports the view expressed by a number of witnesses that home ownership is integral to dignity in retirement, from both a security and an equity point of view. It became evident that adequate retirement planning must take account of major retirement expenses, such as the cost of housing, as well as anticipated income levels. The committee is aware that the ownership of the family home, when combined with superannuation and other investments, will significantly improve the balance of an individual's overall retirement security.

In making its recommendation, the committee recognised that a different significant fall in interest rates has occurred since the major political parties announced the initiative during the last election which had markedly improved housing affordability. The recently announced National Mutual-ACTU super home loans investment trust may also improve affordability—providing interest rates stay down—for some members of the community. However, while these changes are welcome they are unlikely to resolve the difficulty being experienced by some members of the community whose major obstacle is the accumulation of sufficient finance for the initial deposit.

I place on record my disappointment that neither National Mutual nor the ACTU appeared before the inquiry to explain their investment trust initiative, a major development which the government used to abandon its super for housing policy. The Life Insurance Federation of Australia appeared before the committee, but the ACTU unfortunately had difficulty in making itself available to appear. It certainly did not apprise the committee of its super for housing initiative. I am sure some union members might be very disappointed to hear that their peak body did not take the opportunity to put before a parliamentary committee their case on the use of super accumulations for housing purposes.

The committee was also mindful of the potential negative impact of the super for housing proposal on broader government objectives in relation to the superannuation guarantee charge and also national savings. Many who made submissions to the committee expressed concerns that a super for housing scheme could threaten the integrity of superannuation generally and the superannuation guarantee charge in particular. The committee supports that this would certainly be the case should such a scheme be available to all superannuants. So it is the niche market—this particular area—that we are referring to.

It is for this reason that much of the deliberations were devoted to identifying those sections of the community that would gain significant benefits without impacting adversely on the system as a whole. When considering the restrictions on access spelt out in the report and the one-off and tangible nature of housing purchase, the committee believes that the integrity of a superannuation system as such would not be in jeopardy.

It must be remembered that those who the committee has suggested should have access to such a scheme would not be accumulating significant superannuation funds and that such a drawdown would have minimal impact on the value of the age pension they would receive from the government.

This conclusion was drawn upon as a result of figures provided by the retirement income modelling task force, which indicated that a reduction in individual's superannuation accumulations from such a drawdown would result in increasing the amount of age pension received by these superannuants by an average of only $15 per fortnight. When considered against the potential calls for rental assistance of up to $68.40 per fortnight for single recipients without children and $85.85 per fortnight for single recipients with three or more children, it can be seen that the impact on overall government expenditure is likely to be very minimal.

The retirement income modelling task force is a most professional and competent team. Therefore, I trust that the government will see the wisdom of keeping its membership intact in order to undertake important national projects. In summary, the logic on which the committee bases its recommendation that a tightly targeted super for housing scheme has merit for certain sections of the community and should therefore continue to be considered by the government is as follows: the forced savings for retirement under the superannuation guarantee charge has meant that some employees may be receiving lower take-home pay; this is, in turn, increasingly disadvantaging some sections of the community when they seek to save for a deposit to purchase their own home; the lack of a deposit is often a barrier for low income families in gaining access to owner occupancy; the high cost of rental is a major cause of poverty in old age; and those on low incomes are unlikely to accumulate sufficient superannuation to make a significant difference in the level of age pension support required.

Should the government agree to further consideration of a super for housing policy, the committee is unanimous in its belief that it must be developed in close cooperation and consultation with the relevant industry bodies to ensure that it is universally available to the targeted groups. It is important to stress that the committee does not see this proposal as the panacea which would alleviate all cases of housing stress experienced in the general community. A super for housing scheme would only ever be one part of a diverse range of policy initiatives.

Moreover, there are a number of other super and savings issues that need further attention. We commend the government to move in those areas. In preparing its report, the committee has made note of some of these issues and suggested that the solutions proposed by witnesses be considered in more appropriate forums. I take this opportunity to thank all of my colleagues on the committee for a most professional report, and also the members of the secretariat who played a very significant role in preparing this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address a few remarks to the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super for housing. In doing so I commend the report to honourable senators. I think it is well worth reading in order to gain a proper understanding of the complexity of the issues involved. All members of the committee acknowledge that it is a complex issue. The attempt by some commentators to try to make it a simplistic one fails to come to terms with the underlying issues.

PARA.TAB: The thrust of my remarks is designed to explain my motivation in supporting the report and its major recommendation that the government give further consideration to the adoption of a tightly targeted super for housing policy. The report, as the chairman, Senator Watson, commented, represents the unanimous view of the committee. I commend Senator Watson for his work on the report, in chairing the committee and ensuring that the committee maintains the high standards and reputation that it has built.

We tried very hard to stay out of the politics of the issue. It is interesting to note that the report essentially rejects the approaches adopted by both the coalition and the Labor Party prior to the last federal election, which probably means that none of us will be popular. What the report does is highlight the problems and issues that those policies fail to address and it argues for a highly targeted and thereby far more limited proposal to be further developed as a policy option for government.

In my assessment, the weight of evidence received by the committee was against supporting a super for housing policy. The industry adopted an essentially neutral position. It opposed any compulsion regarding a super for housing policy, but did not really give the committee any detailed position on the whole issue. That was one of our concerns, because without greater industry enthusiasm and involvement in the development of the proposal, I do not think it is going to work. There has to be some commitment by the industry to whatever proposal is run with, if one is adopted. I think Senator Watson highlighted that in his remarks.

The industry is clearly not attracted by compulsion, and nor was the Senate committee. We were also concerned that if there is to be equity for persons involved in superannuation, all funds have to take up any super for housing policy. So while we were not attracted by compulsion, nor were we comfortable with a proposition that resulted in a limited take-up and which meant that some people had a super for housing policy available to them while others did not. I think that is one of the key issues that must be resolved.

There are real problems with the proposal for superannuation funding for the private purchase of housing. The work of the retirement income modelling group showed the effect of a withdrawal from superannuation savings: it can have quite a large effect on retirement income. That is obviously a very serious concern. There is potential for the integrity of the superannuation system to be undermined. Nobody on the committee would support anything that went towards that end. I think there is justifiable concern that a super for housing policy could, if we were not careful, encourage over-investment in housing.

Another point to make is that any super for housing policy will not benefit the poor. It will not benefit those who do not have enough income to meet the ongoing repayments needed to service a home mortgage. I think some of the representation of what a super for housing policy would achieve has been a little unreal. The committee makes the point very clearly that the policy would not address the problems of those who are unable to meet ongoing repayments. As the report makes clear, it is not a panacea for social justice.

The committee also took very seriously Dr Vince FitzGerald's comments in his report on national savings. He highlighted that those we were seeking to help might not currently have enough in their superannuation accounts to make the schemes proposed by either political party viable and that it might be some time before the sort of people we are looking to target would have enough savings in superannuation to make a healthy contribution towards a deposit on a home. He also expressed the concern which we shared that one could see the policy being misused, with people using it to invest in larger or more expensive houses, or just facilitating increasing current consumption, but not actually increasing the rate of home ownership. The whole motivation for the policy is to increase the rate of home ownership in our society. FitzGerald's recommendation to the government was—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government could review whether or how direct diversion of super funds into housing can be provided without impairing the long term effectiveness of superannuation.

The committee took that recommendation very seriously. We have tried to address it in presenting our report. But the very clear view of the committee was that the evidence regarding home ownership and the propensity for poverty in retirement was overwhelming; that whether one owned one's own home was a critical issue in determining whether one had a sustainable, comfortable lifestyle in retirement. One could not talk about a proper retirement policy without looking at the consequences of home ownership and making that a very real and large consideration in any retirement income policy.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that concern, the committee supported further consideration of a tightly targeted option that did not threaten the integrity of the system, but which helped those with a deposit gap to gain home ownership. We identified, as Senator Watson said, a niche market—those people who perhaps had the ability to make repayments but did not have the ability to get a deposit together in order to own their own home. Having said that, it is entirely justifiable to conclude, as the government has done, that the difficulties alluded to can lead one to the conclusion that the proposal is just not worth the effort. Certainly, that is a view that I came close to adopting in dealing with the evidence before the committee.

In the end, the committee took the view that we should reject that approach but instead we sought to keep the door open. Despite all the difficulties, we still thought there was a viable policy option that ought to be kept open for the future. That is essentially what we did in our final recommendation. We were not convinced that a carefully crafted solution, combining retirement income policy and housing policy, could not be pulled together.

In the current climate—where housing accessibility reached new highs in 1993, where housing affordability is good with relatively low interest rates, and where large investment in housing is occurring—a super for housing policy initiative is not an imperative. The pressure that was there when both political parties sought to develop a super for housing policy has gone out of the system. Clearly, the imperative is not ranked as highly by anyone in this debate as it was, say, a couple of years ago.

In this climate we can see why people have chosen to concentrate on other policy initiatives or to give them a higher ranking. The committee was clearly aware of that circumstance. It is the case that a super for housing policy is essentially designed to overcome a deposit gap problem. The deposit gap problem is not currently a major issue impacting on housing availability in Australia. It is an important issue for those who cannot get their deposit together, but it is not the major issue currently. The view of most financial institutions at the moment is that the ability to repay a mortgage is the key issue for people seeking to get into their own homes. That, together with the fact that most people we seek to target would not have large amounts currently in their super accounts, means that the time for super for housing as a policy option has not as yet arrived.

In the report we say that the time may come when the pressure will exist in the system again, when the deposit gap problem will be the major issue, and that we would look again at the super for housing policy as a partial solution to that problem. It is clear that, in the future, employees will be contributing more to their own superannuation thereby effectively reducing their disposable income. The problem is that people's disposable income will start to reduce or tighten as they make a bigger contribution to their own superannuation. This will have the effect of increasing their super savings but the money available for housing might reduce.

It is true to say that accessibility to home purchase has been extremely variable in the last decade or so and, while it is high now, it will invariably drop again. I am saying that while the imperative for super for housing is not there currently, it may well be there in the future when those different factors come together. The pressure will be on to find solutions to housing accessibility, for young Australians in particular, and we will be faced with a political reality. The political reality will be that young people with $20,000 or so—some with more, some with less—in their superannuation account will not have enough personal savings to fund a deposit while, on the basis of their income, they will be able to finance repayments. We will be faced with this group of people who have a relatively large amount in their super accounts struggling to make deposits but having the ability to make repayments on a mortgage.

The political reality will be that politicians—senators—will again have to face the issue of the demand for the use of superannuation to finance the purchase of a home. I do not think that the pressure is currently in the system, and that is one of the reasons the government is not pursuing the policy at this time. But the committee is saying that those factors will come together at some stage and that the pressure will be on to respond to a deposit gap problem that people seeking to own their homes will confront. Home ownership is a key factor in providing for a comfortable and reasonable retirement. When those factors I have described come together, it will be necessary to again look at the question of superannuation for housing to allow people to bridge that deposit gap.

In the report we suggest that the industry and the government continue to explore the idea, address the problems that we have identified and try to find a way forward to achieve those two goals—a proper retirement income policy and a housing policy that facilitates as many Australians as possible to own their own homes. Together they provide for the best possible outcome for retirement. The committee is urging further consideration of the issues and we are urging industry to become involved because, without the practical involvement of the industry, any policy devised by a political party will not succeed. Essentially we are leaving the door open for further debate on these quite complex issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of my colleagues on the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation and also to support the 12th report, Super for housing. As I understand it, the report resulted from a reference by the Australian Democrats that was supported by others some time ago. I have to say that we started with a very open mind but we have been convinced that access to super for housing in a very tight policy regime is supportable. Not only do I want to deal with the details of the report, but I also want to address some of the assumptions which lie behind the issue and perhaps signal to the government that it needs to have a look at this issue together with the whole issue of home ownership for retired people.

PARA.TAB: Because of the tax system, investment in one's own home is the very best form of retirement saving with higher post-tax returns than super itself. Yet we are faced with the fact that an increasing number of Australians cannot afford housing, and that certainly includes retired people. Of course, part of the problem is the reduction in public housing in some states. I want to say that lack of housing—not necessarily the very narrow issue that we deal with in this report—for people in their retirement and housing for people in general is an issue of social justice.

Given my background, I am tempted to go into great detail, but tonight I will resist. I simply say that one of the major concerns of the prophetic stream in the Hebrew scriptures is the whole issue of housing. I am reminded of a text which says, `Woe to those who join house to house.' Really, that is a reference to people who, 3,000 years ago, were seeking to control the housing market so as to be able to charge high rents and oppress the poor. It is an issue which has been with us for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Put that in the report!

—Perhaps I should have. With rental housing costs often taking up more than half of the income of retired people, higher home ownership means less post-retirement poverty. This issue was clearly documented in the report. However, I agree that limited access to superannuation deposits would help only some low income earners to reduce the amount they would have to borrow for a first home—in other words, it would help them to do something about the deposit gap.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps it is useful to place on record that before I came into this place I would have been regarded as a reasonably low income earner. Yet, because of the two-tier system of the Uniting Church's beneficiary superannuation fund—called a home acquisition fund—I was able to borrow sufficient money to get a deposit on a house which has enabled me to provide for my retirement.

If we were able to get the government to look again at this issue, I believe that it would result in a higher proportion of retired people owning their own homes. That would certainly address an issue of justice for them. Increasing home ownership should be a vital part of the retirement incomes policy—that is the point I want to make. For that reason, we have opposed, for example, any access to superannuation for home improvement as this does not affect retirement income.

I am very disappointed that the federal government saw fit to pre-empt the report of this committee by dumping its pre-election promise just two or three weeks before the report was to be handed down. I hope that it was not showing some contempt for the Senate or, at least, signalling to the Senate that its reports were of no consequence. Surely I am attributing to the government a motive that was not in its mind, but I do have those kinds of concerns.

The alternative—the ACTU-National Mutual housing loan scheme—delivers a housing interest rate tied to the overnight cash deposit rate. That rate is highly volatile. I admit that at its current seven per cent it is below the housing loan rate of 7.5 per cent, but in the late 1980s it rose to over 20 per cent, well above the then mortgage rate of 17 per cent.

The ACTU-National Mutual scheme could turn into another HomeFund style disaster. Our problem is that we have not been able to access the details of it in order to take them into account. I am very disappointed about that. I would hate to think that many low income earners could be locked into high interest rates and repayments through the ACTU-National Mutual scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it gets off the ground.

—That is right. I am also worried that Minister Brian Howe may not have done us a service by arguing that housing affordability has never been higher. For some people that may be true but only last Friday the Reserve Bank chief, Bernie Fraser, gave a strong warning on this, pointing out that interest rates are likely to rise and that wages are likely to be constrained. That would rapidly reduce housing affordability.

PARA.TAB: In any case, the housing affordability record of banks is woeful. Interest rates were kept as high as 17 per cent for too long, and even though housing interest rates have come down, the banks have been allowed to profiteer. Since December 1989, official interest rates have fallen by 13.25 per cent but mortgage rates have fallen just 8.25 per cent. The difference has been pocketed by the banks. The `big three' banks all recorded higher profits and fatter interest margins last week, thanks largely to housing finance.

This report only seeks to offer one strategy for dealing with the critical issue of retirement housing while there are other strategies—for example, in the public housing area—which the government must employ. However, I want to finish by emphasising the point that higher debt-free home ownership means less post-retirement poverty, and I am sure we all want that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on this 12th report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. In doing so it is wise to recognise that it is the 12th report. This committee has spent a long time looking at the many vexed questions that relate to superannuation and the way in which the structure of superannuation can be used to the best benefit of all Australians.

PARA.TAB: I do not always agree with my colleague Senator Chris Evans but I tend to agree with the conclusions reached by this committee. There was a genuine feeling amongst those of us on the committee that we should come to a conclusion that would most benefit Australians while taking advantage of the current structure of superannuation policies. I am not sure that hastily arranged pre-election promises from any party are a good basis for policy when it comes to deciding the best for future retirees.

There was compelling evidence from some witnesses that superannuation should not be allowed to be used for housing. I am thinking particularly of evidence given to us by Professor John Piggott of the Superannuation Economics Research Group, University of New South Wales. He has appeared before the committee on a number of occasions and the committee has taken great notice of what he has had to say because he has spent a lot of time looking into the question of what is the best form of superannuation for Australians. It is fair to say that he did not recommend using superannuation for housing. However, a number of other people appeared before the committee and we took all their evidence into consideration.

We should never forget that the prime purpose of superannuation is the provision of retirement income. One of the downfalls of the system is that people do not think of superannuation as retirement income but as a form of pension, and different connotations apply. If people were to think of superannuation as retirement income, the future interests of Australians would be better catered for. After all, retirement income is there to provide for us when we no longer have the capacity to earn an income.

The recommendation is that the government give further consideration to the adoption of a highly targeted superannuation for housing policy. It does not say that the government should adopt this policy; it just says that the government should give further consideration to it. I hope that the government will do that because from all the evidence that we received, both written and oral, there was compelling evidence that a certain highly targeted group of people should have access to these funds to help provide the capital required for a deposit on a house.

As Senator Chris Evans said, the difficulty is that those people who might benefit the most—those on very low incomes—are the ones least likely to be able ever to afford a house because they will never have the accumulated funds from which to borrow to provide the deposit. While that is a different problem, it is important for the government to look into the situation to see if it is possible for a group of people to benefit by accessing a part of their superannuation in order to maintain a house.

Owning your own house is the great Australian dream. In many other countries people know that they will never own their own house but in Australia it has always been the tradition that the vast majority will at some stage own their own home. It is almost considered their right. It is a right if people are able to do it, but having the money to do it is another thing.

We were given evidence that perhaps the superannuation industry itself is not particularly geared to lending for housing. Of course, it depends on the way that the policy may be formulated. That is another issue that needs to be addressed.

Before the last election it was part of the coalition's policy to have a tax-free saving scheme. Professor Piggott suggested a more modest form of the same proposal where people are permitted to save out of net of tax income, but not pay any tax on the interest that accrues to those savings until they have purchased their first home. Once the money has been used as a deposit on the first home that right goes away. That would help to remove some of the inequities that Professor Piggott mentioned.

We normally compare ourselves with countries such as Canada, the United Kingdom, the United States and continental Europe. Most of those countries do not have a provision to withdraw pension funds or superannuation funds for housing purchases. Switzerland was the only country that we were made aware of that explicitly mentions housing. Switzerland has a scheme quite like our superannuation guarantee scheme, except that it is supported by a modest social security system. On retirement Switzerland permits the withdrawal of a portion of superannuation benefit as a lump sum for owner-occupied housing purchases.

This committee is trying to address the problem of the finding of the deposit for the initial purchase. This is something that many people, particularly those on low and middle incomes, find so difficult to do.

The committee did not come to its conclusions without a lot of consideration and hearing a lot of evidence. We probably had as broad a range of evidence as it was possible to get, ranging from those who were totally opposed to the use of superannuation money for housing to those who felt that it was the only way that some people would be able to access housing and that it was a right and proper use of superannuation moneys.

Taking all that evidence into account, the committee unanimously came up with this report. I think that indicates that the feeling of the committee was that, whatever we did, we wanted to make sure that we did what we thought was best for Australians; to enable as many Australians as possible to own their own home—something that is becoming a dream rather than a reality. I commend the report and I hope that the government will, at some stage in the future, give consideration to adopting a highly targeted superannuation for housing policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up I wish to thank all my colleagues for their contributions to the debate. This report demonstrates once again that the Senate committee system can find a way through a difficult issue. The immediate feedback and the immediate response shows that the public interest and enthusiasm has been overwhelming.
